questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with jaundice and anemia. His blood smear shows spherical red blood cells, and laboratory tests reveal an increase in mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC). Which of the following is the most likely cause of his anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D.  Hereditary spherocytosis

 

Option D:

 

Hereditary spherocytosis is a genetic disorder characterized by a defect in the red blood cell membrane, leading to a spherical or spheroid shape. Due to the loss of membrane surface area, the concentration of hemoglobin within the smaller, more compacted cells is increased, resulting in an elevated MCHC.

 

Elevated MCHC is a characteristic feature of spherocytes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Iron deficiency anemia: It is characterized by a decrease in the amount of hemoglobin in red blood cells, leading to a decreased MCHC.

 

Option B. Megaloblastic anemia: It can be associated with vitamin B12 or folate deficiency and has macrocytosis. This condition is associated with a normal or decreased MCHC.

 

Option C. Anemia of chronic disease: The anomie is often normocytic and normochromic, with a normal MCH

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hereditary spherocytosis often presents with an elevated MCHC due to the spherical shape of red blood cells, which concentrates the haemoglobin content

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 639

questions.text: A 30-year-old African American male presents to the emergency room with jaundice and dark urine after taking a sulfa drug for a urinary tract infection. He has a past medical history of a similar episode after eating fava beans. His labs reveal hemolytic anemia. Which of the following is NOT a consequence of the enzyme deficiency this patient most likely has?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Decreased RBC membrane damage

G6PD deficiency is associated with decrease in reduced glutathione and decreased NADPH. It is associated with increased lipid peroxidation and more RBC membrane damage.

Option D:

Decreased red blood cell membrane damage is not associated with G6PD deficiency. In fact, the lack of NADPH leads to increased oxidative stress and thus increased membrane damage, causing hemolysis.

Explanation:

Option A. In G6PD deficiency, there is a decrease in reduced glutathione due to insufficient NADPH, leading to decreased ability to neutralize oxidative stress in red blood cells.

Option B. G6PD deficiency results in a decrease in NADPH production, a critical factor in maintaining the reduced state of glutathione.

Option C. Without enough reduced glutathione, red blood cells are more susceptible to oxidative stress, leading to increased lipid peroxidation and membrane damage.

Educational Objective:

Decreased red blood cell membrane damage is not associated with G6PD deficiency.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/e p640

choices.text: Controlling reduction stress on RBC
Controlling oxidative stress on RBC
Maintaining flexibility of cell membrane
Component of electron transport chain

questions.text: A patient presents with an acute hemolytic episode after taking an antimalarial drug. His urine is dark brown, almost black. Laboratory findings are suggestive of intravascular hemolysis. A deficiency in which of the following enzymes is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Controlling oxidative stress on RBC

 Option B:

G6PD helps in neutralizing the effect of oxidative stress on the RBC. Oxidative stress is induced by drugs like primaquine and hence in patients of G6PD there is accelerated hemolysis (intravascular during the hemolytic episode) resulting in hemoglobinuria and passage of shockingly black urine by the patient.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) helps in controlling oxidative stress on RBCs by producing NADPH, which in turn maintains the reduced state of glutathione. Glutathione is vital for detoxifying harmful oxidative agents. Deficiency of G6PD can lead to hemolytic episodes when exposed to oxidative drugs or foods.

Explanation:

Option A. Controlling reduction stress on RBC refers to the balance of redox states within the cell. While redox balance is crucial, there is no specific enzyme known as the ‘reduction stress controller’ in RBCs.

Option C. Maintaining flexibility of cell membrane is related to the cytoskeletal proteins of the RBC, such as spectrin, and does not involve G6PD.

Option D. Components of the electron transport chain are involved in energy production in the mitochondria, which RBCs lack; hence, it does not relate to the integrity of RBCs.

Educational Objective:

The role of G6PD is in maintaining the redox balance to protect RBCs from oxidative stress, where its deficiency can lead to hemolytic anemia upon exposure to certain oxidative drugs or foods.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/640

questions.text: A 10-year-old male presents with jaundice and anemia. His peripheral blood smear shows numerous small, dense, and spherically shaped red blood cells. He reports a family history of similar symptoms. A defect in which of the following is the most likely cause of his anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hereditary spherocytosis

 

Option B:

 

Hereditary spherocytosis is characterized by a genetic defect in the red blood cell membrane proteins, leading to spherically shaped cells that are less deformable and more prone to destruction in the spleen.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  Autoimmune hemolytic anemia is caused by antibodies targeting and destroying red blood cells, not by an intrinsic defect in the red blood cell membrane.

 

Option C. Leading to red blood cell fragmentation Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia is caused by red blood cells being damaged as they pass through narrowed or damaged small blood vessels, not by an intrinsic membrane defect.

 

Option D. Thermal injury causes anemia due to direct heat damage to the red blood cells or indirect effects following burn injury, not due to intrinsic membrane defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hereditary spherocytosis (HS):
    • Autosomal dominant disorder (so usually has a positive family history)
    • Caused by defects in RBC membrane proteins:
    • Most commonly: spectrin, ankyrin, band 3, or protein 4.2
  • Leads to loss of membrane surface area → RBCs become spherocytes:
    • Small, round, dense cells without central pallor
    • Spherocytes are less deformable → get trapped and destroyed in spleen → extravascular hemolysis

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 632
